text: We are making major changes to template errors in the code editor to be more clear and helpful for developers. The first round of changes are out now. Let me know if you see any unusual errors/behavior :pray:
If you would like to see what has changed, make an invalid statement like `{{ "test"|abs }}`

Hi, I wanted to know if I am able to communicate with hubl if I call the url page from a HubSpot workflow? Basically I need to do some logic to provide an unique coupon code for a user, and am seeing if I could avoid having to create a seperate headless site to talk to. And just use HubSpot? If no, any other ways I could potentially do this, or is this not possible at the moment?
You could probably pass it as a parameter on the url and then use HubL to get the parameter on the page.

Question: I have a blog and I'm trying to set it up so works like a timeline. The posts would be filtered by Month. The timeline is a fixed/sticky element on the left that highlights the month as it goes to each grouping. I'm close to completing it, but I'm wondering if there is a better way to add in the fixed timeline... Any thoughts? I only need the month to appear once. (not listed with every post) When you use the default post filter module, you can list them by month but it's essentially just a link... I need it to actually show the posts next to the month in a grouping.
Example mockup just to clarify: <https://i.gyazo.com/35aa72151d06f9d1edc694e7a354564c.png>
Unsure if it will help, but I answered a similar question here `<https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/CMS-Development/Grouping-blog-posts-by-year/m-p/220692#M10226>`.
The demo link no longer works, though

I did something like this for a events calendar, not a blog: <https://www.impactbnd.com/-temporary-slug-df195dec-b300-4b72-844e-a91acdf21dbb?hs_preview=JcEexUoP-6725449653> this achieves the ‘single header’ you are looking for.

 You can use `groupby` to group the posts by the month: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/hubl/hubl-supported-filters>. Then, position absolute that circle with the abbreviated month in the top left corner, relative to a container that wraps around each group (so it follows the posts as you scroll up and down). The javascript on that link above is probably almost perfect for what your need.

Hey <@UFC6BLEAV>, I'm not sure what you're referring to here, but I'd be happy to take a look if you want to share your code and/or what HubL variables/functions you're using from <http://designers.HubSpot.com/docs|designers.HubSpot.com/docs>
Ah I solved this one. ;)
Thanks James
